example:
A: Yo, tryna go to the club tonight?
B: Honestly? I'm not in the mood, deadass. Just wanna stay in.
A: No cap? You're usually the first one out.
B: For real, work just drained my whole energy today.
A: Facts, I feel that. Get some rest, man.
B: Word, catch you tomorrow.
japanese: 気分（きぶん）じゃないんだ。
chinese: 我没心情 (Wǒ méi xīnqíng) / 兴致不高 (Xìngzhì bù gāo)

meaning: 어쩔 수 없어. (나도 나를 못 말려)
example:
A: You're always checking your phone, man.
B: I can't help it, deadass. I'm waiting for that important email.
A: No cap, but you're missing the whole vibe of the park.
B: For real, I'm tryna be more present, but it's hard.
A: Facts, technology really got us locked in.
B: Word, putting it away now.
japanese: 仕方（しかた）ないよ。／どうしようもない。
chinese: 我也没办法 (Wǒ yě méibànfǎ) / 忍不住 (Rěnbùzhù)

example:

japanese: 人（ひと）は多（おお）いほうが楽（たの）しいよ。
chinese: 人多更热闹 (Rén duō gèng rènào) / 越多越好 (Yuè duō yuè hǎo)

example:

chinese: 保守秘密 (Bǎoshǒu mìmì) / 别张扬 (Bié zhāngyáng)

example:

chinese: 别告诉我 (Bié gàosu wǒ) / 我不想听 (Wǒ bù xiǎng tīng)

B: No way! I'm listening, tell me more.

chinese: 洗耳恭听 (Xǐ'ěr gōngtīng) / 听着呢 (Tīngzhe ne)

similar: 5. It’s not the end of the world
example:
A: I failed my driving test again. 
B: Chin up, you'll get it next time. 
A: It's just so frustrating. 
B: Keep your head up, everyone fails once. 
A: Thanks, I needed to hear that. 
B: Don't let it get you down.
japanese: 元気（げんき）出（だ）して／上（うえ）を向（む）いて
chinese: 别灰心 (Bié huīxīn) / 振作起来 (Zhènzuò qǐlái)

example:
A: Did you just drop the vase?
B: Yeah, I'm so ham-fisted today. 
A: You've always been a bit clumsy. 
B: I know, I'm all thumbs when I'm nervous.
A: Just be more careful next time.
B: I'll try not to be such a klutz.
japanese: 不器用（ぶきよう）な／手際（てぎわ）が悪（わる）い
chinese: 笨手笨脚 (Bènshǒubènjiǎo) / 笨拙 (Bènzhuō)

example:
A: Do you still think that movie was terrible?
B: Yes, I stand by it. 
A: But the critics loved the acting.
B: I'm sticking to my guns; it was boring.
A: You're being very stubborn about this.
B: I meant what I said, it wasn't worth the ticket.
japanese: 自分（じぶん）の意見（いけん）を曲（ま）げない／自信（じしん）を持（も）っている
chinese: 我坚持我的观点 (Wǒ jiānchí wǒ de guāndiǎn) / 决不退让 (Jué bù tuìràng)

example:
A: This table is already starting to wobble.
B: The builders probably cut corners. 
A: They shouldn't have skimped on materials.
B: They definitely took the easy way out.
A: We should ask for a refund.
B: Agreed, you can't just do a rush job like this.
japanese: 手抜（てぬ）きをする／楽（ラク）をする
chinese: 偷工减料 (Tōugōngjiǎnliào) / 图省事 (Tú shěngshì)

example:
A: Should I ask him about the breakup?
B: No, don’t bring it up. 
A: I just wanted to see if he's okay.
B: Just leave it alone for now.
A: Fine, I'll drop the subject.
B: Good, it's better not to mention it.
japanese: その話（はなし）はしないで／触（ふ）れないで
chinese: 别提这事儿 (Bié tí zhè shìr) / 别旧话重提 (Bié jiùhuà chóngtí)

example:
A: You look really tense today.
B: I am on the edge with this project. 
A: Is the deadline that close?
B: Yeah, I'm on pins and needles waiting for approval.
A: Take a deep breath, you've got this.
B: I'm at my wit's end, but I'll try.
japanese: 緊張（きんちょう）している／崖（がけ）っぷちだ
chinese: 我快崩溃了 (Wǒ kuài bēngkuì le) / 处在边缘 (Chǔzài biānyuán)

example:
A: Is the boss still angry?
B: Yeah, everyone is walking on eggshells. 
A: I hate having to tiptoe around the office.
B: Me too, it feels like we're on thin ice.
A: Let's just stay quiet today.
B: Good idea, I'm minding my p's and q's.
japanese: 腫（は）れ物（もの）に触（さわ）るように振（ふ）る舞（ま）う／ビクビクする
chinese: 战战兢兢 (Zhànzhànjīngjīng) / 谨小慎微 (Jǐnxiǎoshènwēi)

example:
A: How's that new startup you liked?
B: I think it's starting to fizzle out. 
A: It had so much hype last month.
B: Yeah, but it's really losing steam now.
A: That's a shame, I liked the idea.
B: Most of these trends just fade away.
japanese: 立（た）ち消（き）えになる／尻（しり）すぼみになる
chinese: 逐渐熄灭 (Zhújiàn xīmiè) / 虎头蛇尾 (Hǔtóushéwěi)

example:
A: Do you still talk to your college friends?
B: Not really, we've just drifted apart. 
A: It happens when people move away.
B: Yeah, we slowly grew distant over the years.
A: I miss the old days sometimes.
B: Me too, but we just went our separate ways.
japanese: 疎遠（そえん）になる／心（こころ）が離（はな）れる
chinese: 渐行渐远 (Jiàn xíng jiàn yuǎn) / 疏远了 (Shūyuǎn le)

example:
A: I forgot to back up the data.
B: You of all people should know better! 
A: I know, I was just in a hurry.
B: Especially you, since you're the IT lead.
A: It was a stupid mistake.
B: Out of everyone, I thought you'd be careful.
japanese: よりによってあなたが／まさかあなたが
chinese: 尤其是你 (Yóuqí shì nǐ) / 没想到居然是你 (Méi xiǎngdào jūrán shì nǐ)

example:
A: We need to book the meeting room for 3 PM. 
B: Way ahead of you, I booked it this morning. 
A: Oh, that's perfect. Did you send the invites too?
B: Yep, already on it. Everyone should have it now.
A: You're really on top of things today!
B: I knew we'd need it, so I beat you to it.
japanese: 先（さき）に手（て）を打（う）ってある／お見通（みとお）しだ
chinese: 我早就想到了 (Wǒ zǎo jiù xiǎngdào le) / 领先你一步 (Lǐngxiān nǐ yībù)

meaning: 이럴 확률이 얼마나 될까? (세상 참 좁네)
example:
A: I just ran into my high school teacher in Manhattan. 
B: No way! What are the odds? 
A: I know, I haven't seen him in ten years.
B: It’s such a small world, especially in this city.
A: He was even wearing the same style of tie.
B: Imagine that! What a crazy coincidence.
japanese: こんな偶然（ぐうぜん）ある？／まさか！
chinese: 真是太巧了 (Zhēnshì tài qiǎo le) / 这概率有多大啊 (Zhè gàilǜ yǒu duō dà a)

meaning: 시간을 존중하는 / 시간 약속을 잘 지키는
example:
A: I'll try to keep this presentation under ten minutes. 
B: Thanks, I appreciate you being respectful of time. 
A: I know you have a back-to-back schedule today.
B: I do, so being mindful of the clock is a huge help.
A: I'll get straight to the point then.
B: Great, let's make these minutes count.
japanese: 時間（じかん）厳守（げんしゅ）の／時間（じかん）を大切（たいせつ）にする
chinese: 准时 (Zhǔnshí) / 珍惜时间 (Zhēnxī shíjiān)

example:
A: Let's meet at the cafe at 5 PM. 
B: Wait, I have a call then. Can we do 6?
A: Oh, scratch that, I actually can't do 5 anyway. 
B: Okay, so 6 PM works better for both of us?
A: Actually, never mind, 7 PM is even safer for me.
B: No problem, let's just stick with 7 then.
japanese: 今（いま）のは無（な）しで／取（と）り消（け）すよ
chinese: 刚才那句不算 (Gāngcái nà jù bùsuàn) / 撤回 (Chèhuí)

example:
A: He keeps texting me even though I don't reply. 
B: Wow, he really can’t take a hint. 
A: I’ve been giving him the cold shoulder for days.
B: Some people are just totally oblivious to signs.
A: I might have to be more direct with him.
B: Yeah, he seems way too dense to get it otherwise.
japanese: 空気（くうき）が読（よ）めない／察（さっ）しが悪（わる）い
chinese: 不开窍 (Bù kāiqiào) / 没眼力见 (Méi yǎnlìjiàn)

meaning: 보탬이 될지 모르겠지만 / 그냥 하는 말인데
similar: 4. Take it for what it is
example:
A: I'm really nervous about the interview tomorrow. 
B: For what it’s worth, I think you're the best candidate. 
A: Thanks, that makes me feel a bit better.
B: Just so you know, the boss was impressed with your CV.
A: Really? I didn't know that.
B: If it helps, just be yourself and you'll crush it.
japanese: 参考（さんこう）までに言（い）うと／一応（いちおう）言（い）っておくと
chinese: 不管有没有用 (Bùguǎn yǒu méiyǒu yòng) / 虽说如此 (Suīshuō rúcǐ)

example:
A: Sorry I snapped at you earlier this morning. 
B: It’s okay, I figured you were just stressed.
A: I didn't mean to bite your head off over a coffee.
B: Don't worry about it, we all have those mornings.
A: I’ll try not to lash out like that again.
B: Apology accepted, let's just move on.
japanese: 〜に噛（か）みつく／キレる
chinese: 厉声指责 (Lìshēng zhǐzé) / 没好气地说话 (Méihǎoqì de shuōhuà)

example:
A: Why did you ask me about the budget in front of everyone? 
B: Sorry, I didn't mean to put you on the spot. 
A: You really caught me off guard; I didn't have the numbers.
B: I just thought you might have a rough estimate.
A: Next time, please don't pressure me like that publicly.
B: Got it, I'll check with you privately first next time.
japanese: 困（こま）らせないで／無茶振（むちゃぶ）りしないで
chinese: 让我进退两难 (Ràng wǒ jìntuìliǎngnán) / 让我难堪 (Ràng wǒ nánkān)

example:
A: I had a really rough day at work today. 
B: You need some comfort food. How about ramen? 
A: That sounds perfect, it's my ultimate soul food.
B: Nothing beats a hearty meal after a long day.
A: It’s definitely my guilty pleasure when I'm stressed.
B: Let's go, it'll make you feel much better.
japanese: 心（こころ）が安（やす）らぐ食（た）べ物（もの）／おふくろの味（あじ）
chinese: 舒心食物 (Shūxīn shíwù) / 治愈系美食 (Zhìyù xì měishí)

example:
A: This dinner was quite expensive, let's split it. 
B: No way, it’s on me today. 
A: Are you sure? We can at least split the wine.
B: Nope, I've got this. It’s my treat for your promotion.
A: That's so kind of you, thank you!
B: You're welcome! I'm happy to buy.
japanese: 私（わたし）のおごりだよ。
chinese: 我请客 (Wǒ qǐngkè) / 算我的 (Suàn wǒ de)

example:
A: That was a fantastic dinner. 
B: It really was. Should we split the bill? 
A: Sure, let's just go Dutch this time. 
B: Separate checks makes it easier for everyone. 
A: Let's just divide the tab on the app then. 
B: Perfect, let's split it down the middle.
japanese: 割（わ）り勘（かん）にしよう。
chinese: 各付各的 (Gè fù gè de) / AA制 (AA zhì)

example:
A: How was the new coworking space? 
B: It was okay, but the crowd felt a bit cliquey. 
A: Like they didn't want to talk to outsiders? 
B: Exactly, it felt very exclusive and closed off. 
A: That's annoying when you're trying to network. 
B: Yeah, they stayed in their inner circle all day.
japanese: 排他的（はいたてき）な／内輪（うちわ）乗（の）りの
chinese: 小圈子思想的 (Xiǎoquānzi sīxiǎng de) / 排外的 (Páiwài de)

example:
A: Have you tried the cured mackerel here?
B: I'm not big on fishy flavors.
A: It's not fishy, it's super umami.
B: Fine, I'll take a tiny bite.
A: See? It melts in your mouth.
B: Okay, that's actually legit.
japanese: 鯖（さば）の塩辛（しおから）／しめ鯖（さば）
chinese: 腌制青占鱼 (Yānzhì qīng zhànyú) / 盐水鲭鱼 (Yánshuǐ qīngyú)

example:
A: Any big plans for Sunday morning? 
B: Not really, I'm planning to sleep in. 
A: That sounds amazing, I need the rest too. 
B: I’m just going to lounge in bed until noon. 
A: I wish I could catch some extra Z's like that. 
B: You deserve a late start once in a while!
japanese: 寝坊（ねぼう）する（わざと）／ゆっくり寝（ね）る
chinese: 睡懒觉 (Shuì lǎnjiào) / 晚起 (Wǎn qǐ)

example:
A: You're late! What happened to you? 
B: I'm so sorry, I totally overslept. 
A: Did your phone die or something? 
B: No, I just slept through the alarm completely. 
A: We already started the presentation. 
B: My bad, I'm way behind schedule now.
japanese: 寝坊（ねぼう）した（うっかり）
chinese: 睡过头了 (Shuì guòtóu le) / 误了点儿 (Wù le diǎnr)

example:
A: This hike looks way harder than the map said. 
B: We definitely underestimated the trail. 
A: I thought it would be a breeze. 
B: We shouldn't misjudge the steepness next time. 
A: My legs are already starting to hurt. 
B: Let's not sell the distance short; it's a long way.
japanese: 見（み）くびる／過小評価（かしょうひょうか）する
chinese: 低估 (Dīgū) / 看轻 (Kànqīng)

example:
A: He told me the subway is free on holidays. 
B: And you believed him? You're so gullible. 
A: He sounded so convincing when he said it! 
B: You really shouldn't fall for anything he says. 
A: I guess I'm a bit of a sucker for a good prank. 
B: Seriously, you weren't born yesterday, use your head!
japanese: 騙（だま）されやすい／単純（たんじゅん）な
chinese: 易受骗的 (Yì shòupiàn de) / 天真的 (Tiānzhēn de)

primary: Annoying, irritating, pissed off, fed up with
example:
A: The neighbor's music has been loud all night. 
B: It's so irritating, I'm totally fed up with it. 
A: It's really driving me up the wall. 
B: I'm officially pissed off at this point. 
A: Should we go knock on their door? 
B: Yes, I've had it up to here with the noise!
japanese: 鬱陶（うっとう）しい／イライラする／うんざりだ
chinese: 恼人的 (Nǎorén de) / 厌烦 (Yànfán)

example:
A: Why is he acting so salty after the meeting? 
B: I think I ticked him off by correcting him. 
A: That would definitely ruffle his feathers. 
B: He’s being really bitter about the whole thing. 
A: He always has a chip on his shoulder lately. 
B: Yeah, he gets aggravated way too easily.
japanese: 怒（おこ）らせる／不機嫌（ふきげん）な
chinese: 惹恼 (Rěnǎo) / 闹脾气 (Nào píqi)

example:
A: I'm really sorry I missed your birthday dinner. 
B: Honestly, sorry doesn’t cut it this time. 
A: I'll make it up to you this weekend, I promise. 
B: It's a bit too little, too late for that. 
A: Please give me one more chance. 
B: Actions speak louder than words; show me you care.
japanese: 謝（あやま）って済（す）む問題（もんだい）じゃない
chinese: 道歉也没用 (Dàoqiàn yě méiyòng) / 悔之晚矣 (Huǐ zhī wǎn yǐ)

meaning: 우리 애가 다 컸다, 이제 숙녀가 되었다
example:
A: Is that your niece? She's huge!
B: I know, she's all grown up now.
A: I remember when she was a baby.
B: Time flies. She's applying for college.
A: Makes me feel ancient.
B: Tell me about it, I need a drink.
japanese: 彼女（かのじょ）はすっかり大人（おとな）になったね
chinese: 她长大了 (Tā zhǎngdà le) / 成了大姑娘了 (Chéngle dà gūniang le)

primary: Take it with a grain of salt
meaning: 가려서 들어 / 너무 곧이곧대로 믿지 마
similar: 2. Take it with a pinch of salt
5. Keep an open mind but be skeptical
example:
A: Did you hear the rumor about the company merger? 
B: Yeah, but take it with a grain of salt.
A: Why? It sounded pretty official. 
B: Just consider the source; he loves to exaggerate. 
A: Good point, I shouldn't take it too seriously then. 
B: Exactly, don't buy into it until we hear from the CEO.
japanese: 話（はなし）半分（はんぶん）に聞（き）いておいて／鵜呑（うの）みにしないで
chinese: 别全信 (Bié quán xìn) / 存疑 (Cúnyí)

meaning: 그냥 생각을 입 밖으로 꺼내 본 거야
similar: 4. Thinking off the top of my head
example:
A: Are you saying we should cancel the whole event? 
B: No, I'm just thinking out loud.
A: That sounds like a pretty big decision. 
B: I'm just spitballing here, don't mind me. 
A: Okay, let's look at other options first. 
B: Right, I'm just sharing my thoughts as they come.
japanese: 独（ひと）り言（ごと）だよ
chinese: 随口说说 (Suíkǒu shuōshuo) / 自言自语 (Zìyánzìyǔ)

example:
A: I'm absolutely exhausted after that meeting. 
B: Ditto. I need a nap immediately.
A: It felt like it went on for hours. 
B: My thoughts exactly, it was way too long. 
A: Let's grab lunch and recharge. 
B: I'm with you on that, I'm starving.
japanese: 同感（どうかん）／私（わたし）も
chinese: 我也一样 (Wǒ yě yīyàng) / 同上 (Tóngshàng)

primary: I didn’t sign up for this
meaning: 이건 내가 기대했던 게 아니야 / 이런 건 줄 몰랐어
similar: 1. This isn't what I bargained for
3. This wasn't in the job description
5. Count me out of this part
example:
A: We need you to work every weekend this month. 
B: Whoa, I didn’t sign up for this.
A: It's just a temporary crunch period. 
B: Still, this isn't what I bargained for when I joined. 
A: I understand, but we really need the help. 
B: Sorry, but I'm not down for giving up all my free time.
japanese: こんなはずじゃなかった／これに参加（さんか）した覚（おぼ）えはない
chinese: 这可不是我想要的 (Zhè kě bùshì wǒ xiǎng yào de) / 我没预料到这种情况 (Wǒ méi yùliào dào zhè zhǒng qíngkuàng)

similar: 3. It's not my cup of tea
4. I don't have the stomach for it
example:
A: How are you enjoying the high-pressure sales job? 
B: Honestly, I’m not cut out for it.
A: Is it the constant cold calling? 
B: Yeah, I'm just not built for that kind of rejection. 
A: Maybe you'd prefer a more creative role. 
B: I think so, this definitely isn't my calling.
japanese: 私（わたし）には向（む）いてない
chinese: 我不适合 (Wǒ bù shìhé) / 我不是这块料 (Wǒ bùshì zhè kuài liào)

example:
A: The concert got cancelled due to the rain. 
B: What a bummer! I was so excited.
A: I know, I even bought a new outfit for it. 
B: That really sucks, we've been waiting for months. 
A: At least we can get a refund. 
B: True, but it's still a major drag.
japanese: がっかりだね／残念（ざんねん）
chinese: 真扫兴 (Zhēn sǎoxìng) / 太令人遗憾了 (Tài lìng rén yíhàn le)

example:
A: That tapping sound he makes is so loud. 
B: I know, it's really starting to get on my nerves.
A: Should we ask him to stop? 
B: It's been driving me crazy all morning. 
A: I'll go say something politely. 
B: Thanks, it's really grating on me too.
japanese: 神経（しんけい）に障（さわ）る／イライラさせる
chinese: 让我心烦 (Ràng wǒ xīnfán) / 触动我的神经 (Chùdòng wǒ de shénjīng)

meaning: 나를 좀 인정해 줘 / 나를 너무 무시하지 마
example:
A: Are you sure you can handle this technical part? 
B: Come on, give me some credit.
A: I just know it's a bit complicated. 
B: I've done this dozens of times, I'm not that clueless. 
A: My bad, I didn't mean to doubt you. 
B: Thanks, just acknowledge my experience once in a while.
japanese: もう少（すこ）し信用（しんよう）してよ／見直（みなお）してよ
chinese: 给我点面子 (Gěi wǒ diǎn miànzi) / 承认我的努力 (Chéngrèn wǒ de nǔlì)

example:
A: How did you end up living in New York? 
B: I just found myself in a position to move and took it.
A: It must have been a big change. 
B: It was, but I landed in a great neighborhood. 
A: I'd love to wind up in a city like that someday. 
B: You should, it's an incredible place to find yourself facing new challenges.
japanese: 気（き）づいたら〜にいた／〜という状況（じょうきょう）に陥（おちい）る
chinese: 发现自己处于 (Fāxiàn zìjǐ chǔyú) / 偶然陷入 (Ǒurán xiànrù)

similar: 1. If you're in the mood to
example:
A: I'm heading to the gym now. 
B: If you ever feel like joining, let me know. 
A: I’m not really in the mood to work out today. 
B: No worries, if you're up for it tomorrow, just call. 
A: Thanks, I might take you up on that. 
B: Great, the offer stands whenever you're ready.
japanese: もし〜したくなったら／気（き）が向（む）いたら
chinese: 如果你什么时候想 (Rúguǒ nǐ shénme shíhòu xiǎng) / 只要你愿意 (Zhǐyào nǐ yuànyì)

example:
A: We’re falling behind on the marketing plan. 
B: We really need to keep things on track. 
A: Let's set some strict deadlines for each phase. 
B: Good idea, we can't afford to get sidetracked now. 
A: I’ll send out the updated schedule today. 
B: Perfect, let's stay on target and finish this.
japanese: 順調（じゅんちょう）に進（すす）める／脱線（だっせん）させない
chinese: 确保一切顺利 (Quèbǎo yīqiè shùnlì) / 步入正轨 (Bù rù zhèngguǐ)

primary: Stop complaining / don't be so dramatic / cry me a river
meaning: 불평 좀 그만해 / 오버하지 마 / 어디 한번 실컷 짜보시지
example:
A: This line is taking forever, my life is over! 
B: Oh, cry me a river, it’s only been five minutes. 
A: But I have so much to do today! 
B: Stop being so dramatic and just wait. 
A: You’re so insensitive to my suffering. 
B: Seriously, quit your whining and look at your phone.
japanese: 文句（もんく）言（い）うな／大袈裟（おおげさ）にするな／泣（な）き言（ごと）は聞（き）きたくない
chinese: 别抱怨了 (Bié bàoyuàn le) / 有什么好哭的 (Yǒu shénme hǎo kū de)

meaning: 내가 총대를 멜게 / 비난은 내가 감수할게
example:
A: The client is going to be furious about the delay. 
B: Don't worry, I'll take the heat for this one. 
A: Are you sure? It was a team mistake. 
B: I'm the lead, so I'll handle the backlash. 
A: That’s very brave of you, thanks. 
B: It’s fine, I’ll take the fall and explain the situation.
japanese: 私（わたし）が責任（せきにん）を取（と）る
chinese: 我来承担责任 (Wǒ lái chéngdān zérèn) / 挨骂也值了 (Āimà yě zhí le)

primary: I'm stuck between A and B.
similar: 1. I'm torn between A and B
example:
A: Have you decided on the vacation spot yet? 
B: I'm stuck between Japan and Italy. 
A: Both sound amazing, but they are so different. 
B: Exactly, I’m totally torn between the two. 
A: Japan is closer, but Italy has better food. 
B: I know! I'm in a real dilemma here.
japanese: AとBで迷（まよ）っている
chinese: 我在AB之间左右为难 (Wǒ zài AB zhījiān zuǒyòu wéinán) / 纠结不定 (Jiūjié bùdìng)

example:
A: Should I accept the job offer right now? 
B: It’s a big move, maybe you should sleep on it. 
A: I’m afraid they might give it to someone else. 
B: They’ll wait a day; just take some time to think. 
A: You're right, I'll mull it over tonight. 
B: Good, things always look clearer in the morning.
japanese: 一晩（ひとばん）考（かんが）えさせて
chinese: 考虑一晚 (Kǎolǜ yī wǎn) / 容我再想想 (Róng wǒ zài xiǎngxiǎng)

primary: You are quite bold / You've got some nerve
similar: 4. You've got a lot of gall
example:
A: I asked the CEO for a 50% raise today. 
B: Wow, you've got some nerve! 
A: Why? I’ve been working really hard lately. 
B: It’s just that you are quite bold to ask for that much. 
A: If you don't ask, you don't get, right? 
B: True, you've definitely got some gutsy energy.
japanese: いい度胸（どきょう）してるね／図々（ずうずう）しいね
chinese: 你胆子真大 (Nǐ dǎnzi zhēn dà) / 好大的胆子 (Hǎo dà de dǎanzi)

primary: Keep it to yourself / Keep a lid on it
meaning: 너만 알고 있어 / 비밀로 해 줘
example:
A: Did you hear that Sarah is quitting next month? 
B: Yeah, but keep it to yourself for now. 
A: I won't tell anyone, I promise. 
B: Seriously, keep a lid on it until it's official. 
A: My lips are sealed, I'll stay mum. 
B: Thanks, we don't need any office rumors yet.
japanese: ここだけの話（はなし）にしておいて／他言無用（たごんむよう）で
chinese: 别告诉别人 (Bié gàosu biérén) / 保密 (Bǎomì)

primary: If you are clued in, you'll get it / If you know, you know
similar: 5. You either get it or you don't
example:
A: Why is everyone wearing green ribbons today? 
B: If you are clued in, you'll get it. 
A: Is it some kind of secret club or something? 
B: If you know, you know, I can't say more. 
A: Come on, just tell me if I'm in the loop or not. 
B: You'll figure it out soon enough, just watch.
japanese: 分（わ）かる人（ひと）には分（わ）かる／通（ツウ）なら分（わ）かる
chinese: 知情者自明 (Zhīqíngzhě zìmíng) / 懂的都懂 (Dǒng de dōu dǒng)

example:
A: Can I help you find anything specific today? 
B: No thanks, I'm just browsing. 
A: Feel free to ask if you need a different size. 
B: I appreciate it, I'm just window shopping for now. 
A: Our new collection is over in that corner. 
B: Thanks, I'll just keep looking around.
japanese: ただ見（み）ているだけです（店員に対して）
chinese: 我随便看看 (Wǒ suíbiàn kànkàn) / 只是逛逛 (Zhǐshì guàngguang)
